http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/MRC/commerci: One hundred nineteen cigarette commercials with numerous celebrity endorsements by actors, actresses and sports figures, produced between in the 1950s through 1970s. Includes adds with the "Marlboro Man" enjoying his cigarettes while fishing, as a pilot, ranch hand, skeet shooting, camping and Kayaking. Concludes with a 1954 Encyclopedia Britannica film "Tobacco and the human body" which was among the first to report on the health problems associated with smoking. Member of the Family: With this film we see another trip half way around the World and discover that the effects of Coca-Cola resound everywhere. Disc 1: Always tomorrow : [portrait of an American business] / Coca-Cola Company ; a Jam Handy picture (1941, 52 min.) -- The refreshing look / sponsored by the Vendo Company (1960s, 16 min.) -- Disc 2: Pearl of the Orient (1955, 22 min.) -- Coca Cola Bottling Plant - Arabia (1950s, 10 min.) -- Wonderful world (1950s, 33 min.) -- Member of the family (1954, 11 min.) Features six vintage Coca-Cola films, filmed in the United States and all around the world. A good educational use of these films is for studying the Post-WWII rise of consumerism and globalization. Always tomorrow: This 52 minute feature film shows the beginnings of the Coca-Cola company and the heart and soul of the people who were involved in starting it. Refreshing look: Classic vending machine film sponsored by The Vendo Company and Coke, which encourages store owners to buy a Vendo machine filled with Coca Colas on the merits of the vending machines profitability. Pearl of the Orient: This is a beautiful film about the relationship between Coke products and culture in the Philippines. Includes many shots of local customs, manufacturing and farming. Coca Cola Bottling Plant - Arabia: A fascinating film narrated in the Arabic language about manufacturing Coca-Cola in the Middle East. Wonderful World: According to this film, Coke products are found around the World and bring great joy to people, no matter their culture.

TV commercials, promotional spots, and public service announcements were produced on 16mm, spooled onto mini-reels, and projected into a film-chain for telecast. They usually had a limited shelf life and were considered disposable. After a brief rotation on the air, most of them were discarded, never to be seen again. This production is a salvaged collection from the 1970s of ads, information clips, and PSA's as found in their original 16mm format that offer a glimpse into a history that was never meant to be remembered.

A collection of 150 classic television commercials from the 1950's-1970s. Includes adds for personal hygiene products, food, cigarettes, beer, cleaning products, candy, toys, automobiles, medicines and many others. Highlights feature a public service announcement by Ronald Reagan for atomic power; Lucille Ball plugging Boraxo soap, Euell Gibbons for Post cereals, Boris Karloff for the Forest Lawn Mortuaries; a re-election campaign add for Houston I. Flournoy and Lloyd Bridges for Big Brothers of L.A., and Tom Brokaw for the Los Angeles News Service. 109 min.

TV commercials from China, Hong Kong, Australia, Singapore, Japan, India, Canada and the Republic of Korea are highlighted with commentary by advertising executives from each of the countries. 1999. 49 min.
